newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: PRESS DIGEST - South Korean newspapers - June 30.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - South Korean newspapers - June 30.

text.p: The following is a summary of major stories in leading South Korean newspapers, prepared by Reuters in Seoul. Reuters has not checked the stories and does not guarantee their accuracy.

- President Kim Young-sam will hold a meeting on Tuesday with Lee Hoi-chang, chairman of the ruling New Korea Party, amid expectations that Lee will step down to seek the party's nomination for presidential elections in December. Later this week, Kim is expected to meet other party officials seeking nomination.

- The law enforcement authorities of Switzerland recently found secret bank accounts of former President Roh Tae-woo who is serving a 17-year jail term for corruption and human rights abuses. Most of the deposits have been withdrawn.
- The ruling New Korea Party on Sunday started accepting registrations by candidates seeking party nomination for presidential elections in December.
- The Korean ecconomy could most likely turn around at the end of the 3rd quarter: industrial output growth slows to 6.1 percent in May.

- Hong Kong entered its penultimate day of British rule on Sunday with a farewell radio address from its last governor Chris Patten, who decried as "nonsens" arguments that the territory cares only for money, not democracy.
- South Korea and Hong Kong will sign the Agreement for the Promotion and Protection of Investments today.
- President Kim Young-sam has indicated that he may reshuffle his cabinet next month.
